One step at a time... Bitcoin's energy mix is already "greener" than that of, say, JP Morgan.
Early borrowers may be miners or bitcoin vendors. Gold doesn't have a stable value either, yet it was the borrowing standard for centuries.
Bitcoin mining converts electricity into trustless financial reliability.
Bitcoin mining doesn't affect retail rates, different energy production facilities.
Bitcoin mining is a fantastic use case for low cost energy produced in remote areas: instant monetization, high probability of increased demand in coming years.

Not to mention, the Bitcoin community absolutely hates its own miners, so it's a bit weird to see someone boasting of BTC's hash power.

"Bitcoin's Security" is a false narrative. It's a myth that the coin is more secure because it has more hash power, because the security bottlenecks lie at the exchanges, where the coins are stored. Liquidity is a thing, though.

Simple econ tells us that Bitcoin transaction volume (and coin dominance) should drop until its fees are slightly above the fees that the other currencies charge for the same function of transferring value. That's exactly what we see. https:// bitinfocharts.com/comparison/tra nsactions-btc-sma3.html …

Huh -- I guess I wonder then why the Silk Road didn't adopt dollar payments, and Ransomware didn't expand exponentially before Bitcoin ransom payments were possible. I guess it's just chance!

there aren't numbers on any of this yet -- just anecdotal evidence from police on what they are seeing and what they saw before this. there was broad agreement among people i spoke to that the dark net + bitcoin payments had allowed fentanyl to get places it wouldn't have before

If you want to talk about how Bitcoin allows for new, cool things that weren't possible -- or as easy -- before Bitcoin, it shouldn't be surprising if people also want to talk about the new, bad things that weren't possible -- or as easy -- before Bitcoin.

Early users of Bitcoin, including Satoshi, knew this and assumed that drugs and porn users would be the most obvious early audience for Bitcoin. Bitcoin offered them something that traditional payment methods did not https:// bitcointalk.org/index.php?topi c=175.0 …

Unlike the dollar, Bitcoin was specifically designed to work around the kind of oversight that might be able to stop bad actors from using it. As a result, criminals are now able to do things that they could not do -- or not do nearly as easily -- with the dollar.
I often get asked: Why do you talk so much about the bad guys using Bitcoin to commit crimes if you don't blame the dollar when people use it to do bad things?
